meaning_mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <radical>sword</radical>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <kanji>sword</kanji>? That's right, the most common is a <kanji>katana</kanji>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
The <radical>dirt</radical> radical and the <kanji>dirt</kanji> kanji are the same!
This kanji is the same as the radical you learned, so it means <kanji>thousand</kanji>.
The <radical>evening</radical> radical and the <kanji>evening</kanji> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
The <radical>child</radical> radical and the <kanji>child</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
The <radical>small</radical> radical and the <kanji>small</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>street</kanji>.
What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.

On the <radical>ground</radical> you put <radical>barb</radical>s at the bottom of a <radical>slide</radical>. This is your special <kanji>talent</kanji>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent.
The radical <reading>middle</reading> and the kanji <kanji>middle</kanji> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
The <radical>five</radical> radical and the <kanji>five</kanji> kanji are the same.

Just imagine a beast with a <radical>lid</radical> for a head and <radical>fins</radical> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <kanji>six</kanji> is the devil's number.

Here we have a <radical>head</radical> with a <radical>lid</radical> in it, near the top. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <kanji>yen</kanji> coins, the currency of Japan. Jackpot! And all those yen coins have a nice <kanji>round</kanji> shape, naturally.
The radical <radical>heaven</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>heaven</kanji>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
The <radical>hand</radical> radical and the <kanji>hand</kanji> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>writing</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>writing</kanji> as well.

The <radical>sun</radical> radical and <kanji>sun</kanji> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <kanji>day</kanji> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
The <kanji>moon</kanji> kanji is made up of the <radical>moon</radical> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>month</kanji>.
This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>tree</kanji> are the same in looks and meaning.
The <radical>water</radical> radical and the <kanji>water</kanji> kanji are the same.
The <radical>fire</radical> radical and the <kanji>fire</kanji> kanji are the same as each other.
The <radical>dog</radical> radical and <kanji>dog</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
The <radical>king</radical> radical and the <kanji>king</kanji> kanji are the same!

There are two <radical>mountains</radical> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <kanji>exit</kanji> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.

<radical>Narwhal</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s are on the <kanji>right</kanji> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

See how the "mouth" radical is to the right of the "narwhal" radical? That should help you remember that this means <kanji>right</kanji>.

Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <radical>mouth</radical> now has your <radical>legs</radical> inside it. You've bent your body in all the wrong ways to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <kanji>four</kanji> sides.
<radical>Narwhal</radical>s do <radical>construction</radical> with their <kanji>left</kanji> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>book</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>book</kanji> as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <kanji>origin</kanji>, <kanji>real</kanji>, and <kanji>main</kanji>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.

There is a line on the <radical>ground</radical> so you <radical>stop</radical>, making a giant sign pop up that says <kanji>CORRECT</kanji>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.
The <radical>king</radical> has a big <radical>drop</radical> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <kanji>ball</kanji>.
The <radical>rice paddy</radical> radical and the <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
The radical <radical>white</radical> and the kanji <kanji>white</kanji> are the same.
The <radical>eye</radical> radical and <kanji>eye</kanji> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
The radical <radical>stand</radical> and the kanji <kanji>stand</kanji> are the same thing, so now you know them both.

This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. It repeats what comes before it.

To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a <radical>prison</radical> with <radical>drop</radical>s of water dripping over and over in it. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.
